As DfLevel 3. WonderkidUpdated on 07 Jun 2019Consider the source of the advice - will whoever is recommending the action benefit from it? What exactly are the benefits and USP it has? (And no, "my cousin's sister in law's lawyer friends' secondary school class mate said so and he works for Warren Buffet so bao jiak" or " trust me I'm a (self proclaimed) guru and I won't con my friends/relatives/colleagues etc " doesn't cut it)​Look for counter opinions - If it's such a wonder product, why isn't everyone rushing to get it? What are the reasons of the naysayers?​Engage common sense - which side sounds more rational to you? Double check whatever numbers they spouted with a independent source (e.g. If they say property prices has doubled every 10 years Google for statistics to see if it has done so) and then think if it's even relevant to the point they are making.​Decide on your own.​​1 comment1
